Background: As part of the Climate Protection Programme 2030, the German government has already decided to invest an additional 1 billion euros per year in Deutsche Bahn from 2020 to 2030. This will enable Deutsche Bahn to invest additional capital in the modernisation, expansion, and electrification of the rail network and the railway system.  To be able to achieve this goal, and in view of the corona-related revenue shortfalls, the Federal Government will provide Deutsche Bahn with an additional equity capital of EUR 5 billion.

Name of policy: Bus and truck fleet modernization
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: To increase the demand for e-buses and make urban transport more environmentally friendly
Background: The federal government is investing in a "Bus and Truck Fleet Modernization Program", which is open to private and municipal operators alike to promote alternative drive systems. To increase the demand for e-buses and make urban transport more environmentally friendly, funding for e-buses and their charging infrastructure will also be increased for a limited period until the end of 2021.

Name of policy: Support for accelerated conversion to more efficient types of aircraft
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: To support accelerated conversion to more efficient types of aircraft
Background: Modern aircraft of the latest design emits up to 30% less CO2 and noise. This policy is meant to support the accelerated conversion to the new types of aircraft.

Name of policy: 9-hour free solar power for farmers
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Background: The Government of Andhra Pradesh had promised 9 hours of free power during the daytime to farmers, this has been approved, allocating solar power to fulfill this supply requirement. The cabinet had previously approved solar power projects amounting to 10,000 MW capacity for this purpose.

Name of policy: Modernisation fund for shipping, including traffic innovation and support for renewing government vessels.
Stage: several energy stages
Objectives: To strengthen, modernise, and digitise shipping as a climate-friendly means of transport
Background: This policy is meant to strengthen, modernise and digitise shipping as a climate-friendly means of transport. This includes, among other things, bank rehabilitation, modernisation of locks, replacement of vessels and digital test fields. The innovation support established by the Federal Government in the field of shipping, the Maritime Research Programme, the Land Electricity Support Programme, a new "LNG refuelling vessels support programme", a "fleet renewal programme for government vessels," and a new "Clean Ships Immediate Programme" will be provided with an additional 1 billion euros for projects starting in 2020 and 2021.

Name of policy: Coal washing requirement for supply to TPPs removed
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change
Background: MoEFCC amended the Environment Protection Act to drop mandatory washing coal for supply to thermal power plants. The ministry is of the view that the requirement of maintaining an average ash content of 34% prompts industries to import, resulting in an outflow of foreign exchange. The ministry has instead directed thermal power plants to install the technology for handling ash content.

Name of policy: Increased borrowing limited for states pegged to power sector reforms (Atma Nirbhar Bharat Abhiyan)
Stage: electricity storage or transmission or distribution
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Ministry of Finance in co-ordination with the Ministry of Power
Objectives: To help states tackle financial burden of dealing with C-19 issues
Background: Centre has permitted States to exceed their borrowing capacities upto additional net borrowing space of a cumulative 2% of gross state domestic product, or Rs 4.28 lakh crore in FY21, upon satisfying measurable targets in 4 sectors, of which one is power (total of 0.25% GDP state borrowing). 0.1% of GDP borrowing space is linked to reducing AT&C losses of discoms and also reducing the gap between average cost of supply and average revenue realisation (ACS-ARR gap). 0.15% is linked to implementation of Direct Benefit Transfer scheme atleast in one district by December 2020.

Name of policy: Coal India Limited Investment Decision in Coal Transportation Infrastructure
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Objectives: Primary: To improve efficiency of the coal production system
Background: The allocation is to develop India's coal transportation infrastructure and is a part of the broader plan to support higher domestic production of coal and curtail imports.

Name of policy: Rebates on Coal Extraction
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Ministry of Coal / Ministry of Finance
Background: Stimulus package offers 50% rebate on revenue payable to the government for coal extraction projects that begin early production or exceed a scheduled target and a 20% reduction for coal gasification projects.

Name of policy: Liquidity boost for power distribution companies (Atma Nirbhar Bharat Abhiyan, Tranche 1)
Stage: electricity generation
Background: Distribution companies (DISCOMs) are facing cash-flow problems owing to the delayed payment measures offered to consumers and the overall fall in demand. DISCOMs have also not been able to offtake the cheapest sources of power owing to the Government's directive regarding prioritising certain sources of power, including renewables. This has led to a major strain on DISCOM finances.

Name of policy: Free LPG cylinders under Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana to 80000000 beneficiaries of Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas
Objectives: To help consumers cope with the economic impacts of Covid-19
Background: To provide a clean cooking solution, the government launched the PMUY which gave free LPG connections. So far over 80 million households have been connected via this programme. Due to the national lockdown to prevent the spread of C-19, many rural communities are facing economic hardships. To ease their burden, the government has announced 3 LPG cylinders for free between April-June, 2020 under the Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana. Each of these cylinders has 14.2 kg of LPG. The scheme was extended to September 2020 to ensure that the beneficiaries are able to avail the free cylinders.

Name of policy: Commercial Mining of Coal
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Background: The amendment opens up the coal mining sector to commercial mining by removing the coal end-use restriction (for captive consumption) on private parties. The aim of this amendment is to make cheaper and larger quantities of domestic coal available. It also removes some eligibility restrictions such as prior experience in the sector requirements. UPDATE: 41 coal blocks were listed for commercial auction on June 18th.

Name of policy: Excise duty hiked on retail sale of gasoline and diesel
Stage: several energy stages
Objectives: Primary: To raise state finances to help with the tight fiscal situation
Background:
This policy allows the government to increase excise duty on petrol and diesel by Rs 2 per litre (petrol) and Rs 4 per litre (diesel) to meet unexpected expenses during Covid-19.
This was subsequently increased on May 6 by Rs 10 per litre for petrol and Rs 13 per litre for diesel

Name of policy: Economic Recovery Program: Bailout for PT Kereta Api Indonesia (Railway SOE)
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: President Regulation (Act class) / Ministry of Finance
Objectives: To avoid SOEs from going bankrupt. Interpretation of Indonesian SOE Act implies that SOEs are not allowed to be bankrupt
Background:
The Government prepared 3 programs with total funds of IDR 152.15 trillion
The injection funds will be divided into three scenarios, namely in the form of state capital participation (PMN) worth IDR 25.27 trillion, compensation payment of IDR 94.23 trillion, and investment bailout IDR 32.65 trillion. This last scheme will be enjoyed by Garuda Indonesia (Airline SOE), KRAS, Bulog, KAI(Train SOE), PTPN, and Perumnas.
PLN (electricity SOE) is set to receive IDR 45.5 trillion in compensation payment and participation of state capital
Links to sources:

Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation

Background:
The Government prepared 3 programs with total funds of IDR 152.15 trillion

PLN (electricity SOE) is set to receive IDR 45.5 trillion in compensation payment and participation of state capital

PLN (electricity SOE) is set to receive IDR 45.5 trillion in compensation payment and participation of state capital

Name of policy: Economic Recovery Program:Compensation Payment to PLN
Stage: several energy stages
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: President Regulation (Act class) / Ministry of Finance
Objectives: To avoid SOEs from going bankrupt. Interpretation of Indonesian SOE Act implies that SOEs are not allowed to be bankrupt
Background:
The Government prepared 3 programs with total funds of IDR 152.15 trillion
The injection funds will be divided into three scenarios, namely in the form of state capital participation (PMN) worth IDR 25.27 trillion, compensation payment of IDR 94.23 trillion, and investment bailout IDR 32.65 trillion. This last scheme will be enjoyed by Garuda Indonesia (Airline SOE), KRAS, Bulog, KAI(Train SOE), PTPN, and Perumnas.
PLN (electricity SOE) is set to receive IDR 45.5 trillion in compensation payment and participation of state capital

Name of policy: Solar energy program as part of post Covid-19 recovery
Stage: electricity generation
Background: The plan is to subsidize rooftop solar plant installations in households. More details will follow.

Name of policy: Suspension and elimination of Value Added Tax (VAT) and Income Tax for various RE Projects
Stage: electricity generation
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Background: MEMR has identified the impact of COVID19-19 by issuing a number of policies to counter these negative effects. They are now focusing on a number of incentives and concessions on the renewable energy business in the COVID-19 affected areas.

Name of policy: Subsidies  for the utilization of biodiesel-type biofuel
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Background: MEMR has identified the impact of COVID-19 by issuing a number of policies to counter these negative effects. They are now focusing on a number of incentives and concessions on the renewable energy business in the COVID-19 affected areas.

Name of policy: Relaxation of Commercial Operation Date (COD) and the elimination of financial penalties to adjust the procurement mechanism of Independent Power Producer (IPP)
Stage: electricity generation
Background: MEMR has identified the impact of COVID-19 by issuing a number of policies to counter these negative effects. They are now focusing on a number of incentives and concessions on the renewable energy business in the COVID-19 affected areas. This policy will be focused on accelerating the labour-intensive and decentralized RE projects, such as rooftop PV in government offices and cold storage, and off-grid micro-hydro and solar PV projects.

Name of policy: Suspension of loan installments and lowering interest rates for Renewable Energy projects.
Stage: electricity generation
Background: Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources has identified the impact of COVID-19 by issuing a number of policies to counter these negative effects. They are now focusing on a number of incentives and concessions on the renewable energy business in the Covid-19 affected areas.

Name of policy: Industrial gas price reduction USD 0.06 / MMBTU
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)

Name of policy: 3 months electricity bill exemption for residential 450 VA customers and 50% discount for residential 900 VA customers
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: President Regulation (Act class) Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Energy, and PLN
Background: The facility is given to Indonesian poor since the electricity subsidy database matches the poverty database. This measure as classified as "fossil unconditional" because most of Indonesia's electricity comes from fossil fuels.

Name of policy: Tax relaxation on international trade in relation to COVID19 & Crisis that can harm national economy
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: President Regulation (Act class) / Ministry of Finance
Background: New customs facilities which give the authority to the Minister of Finance to provide customs facilities other than those stipulated in Article 25 paragraph 1 of the Customs Law.

Name of policy: Exemption of VAT and Income Tax
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: President Regulation (Act class) / Ministry of Finance
Background: VAT exemptions for items needed in handling the Covid-19 outbreak such as drugs, vaccines, laboratory equipment, detection equipment, PPE, equipment for patient care, and other supporting equipment. Whereas in the service sector, the government also provides VAT exemptions for services needed in handling the Covid-19 outbreak such as construction services, consulting services, engineering, and management, rental services, and other supporting services.

Name of policy: Deferral of Tax Payment (max. 6 months)
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: President Regulation (Act class) / Ministry of Finance
Background: Extension of the application period or completion of tax administration. In this case, the extension of the period of submission of objections by taxpayers is extended to a maximum of 6 months from 3 months to nine months. The extension of the settlement period by the Directorate General of Tax (DGT) is also extended to a maximum of six months for requests for restitution through examination and objection requests from 12 months to 18 months. Furthermore, requests for reduction or elimination of administrative sanctions from 6 months to 12 months.

Name of policy: Discount on  Corporate Income Tax for Public Company (3% discount)
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: President Regulation (Act class) / Ministry of Finance
Background:
A reduction in the corporate income tax (PPh) from 25% to 22% for the 2020-2021 tax year. Followed by another reduction to 20% for the tax year 2021

There is an additional 3% discount for companies classified as issuers (40% public shares), so that the issuer's Corporate Income Tax becomes 19% in the tax year 2020-2021, and in 2022 it becomes 17%.

Name of policy: Access to Eskom, Sasol and Arcelor Mittal’s pollution records
Stage: several energy stages
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: The Ministry of the Environment, Forestry and Fisheries
Objectives: Increasing access to information.
Background: The Minister of the Environment, Forestry and Fisheries, Barbara Creecy has ordered her department to disclose future information about the GHG emissions of the country's biggest polluters.

Name of policy: Lowered pollution standards for SO2 emitters
Stage: several energy stages
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: The Ministry of the Environment, Forestry and Fisheries
Background: The Minister of the Environment, Forestry and Fisheries, Barbara Creecy, published SO2 air pollution standards twice as low as previous standards at the start of the Covid-19 emergency lockdown.

Name of policy: New amendments to the Mineral Resources Development Act (MPRDA)
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Objectives: Facilitate new mining projects
Background: Mineral Resources and Energy Minister Gwede Mantashe has released new amendments to the Mineral Resources Development Act which undermine the right of affected communities to oppose mining projects

Name of policy: Deferral of first carbon tax payment and filing of tax returns
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Carbon Tax Act 15 of 2019, Ministry of Finance
Objectives: To provide cash flow relief and to alleviate some of the compliance burden on taxpayers, a three-month deferral of the first period for submission of accounts and carbon tax payments is proposed.
Background: Due to COVID-19 and the subsequent lockdown, many industries and businesses have closed. As such, it is argued that they have decreased income and also are polluting less. The rationale for this is then to allow them a 'payment holiday' for carbon tax emissions due to the reasons above. To provide cash flow relief and to alleviate some of the compliance burdens on taxpayers, a three-month deferral of the first period for submission of accounts and carbon tax payments is proposed."

Name of policy: Wind power supply disruptions
Stage: electricity generation
Objectives: Manage the reduced demand for electricity by relying on fewer variable sources of energy generation.
Background: Eskom has issued a Force Majeure to curtail wind power producers from supplying power to the grid. This is because demand is expected to fall; this directly affects the power purchase agreements between Eskom and Renewable Energy Independent Power Producers (REIPPs)

Name of policy: IDC providing working capital to suppliers of primary energy
Stage: several energy stages
Objectives: Funding to boost primary energy suppliers (alongside other essential sectors).
Background: The Industrial Development Corporation has allocated R3 billion in funding for firms that produce essential goods to scale up their operations. This includes the energy sector and specifically, primary energy suppliers.

Name of policy: Increase in the subsidy for converting vehicles to gas-fired engines from 30% to 60% of the total retrofitting costs
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Decree of the Government of the Russian Federation № 886 of 19 June 2020 "On Amendments to the Annex № 29 to the State Programme of the Russian Federation "Development of the Energy Sector
Objectives: To stimulate domestic demand for gas and to convert transport fleet to gas.
Background: The government increased its subsidy for converting cars, trucks and other vehicles to gas-fired engines from 30% to 60%. Gazprom will cover another 30%. Vehicle owners will only have to pay 10% of the costs.

Name of policy: Airline subsidies due to coronavirus traffic decreases
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Decree of May 13, 2020 No. 661/Government of Russia (Ministry of Transport)
Objectives: To help airlines survive the period of restrictions associated with the difficult epidemiological situation and maintain employment.
Background: The subsidies are calculated as follows: airlines will be paid RUB 365 for each passenger lost in the reporting month of 2020 compared to the same month of 2019, from February to July. Airlines can use the subsidies to cover salaries for pilots and flight attendants, payments to Russian leasing companies and for airport services.

Name of policy: Partial compensation of operation costs by airports
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Decision of the Government of Russia № 1436-р of 29 May 2020
Objectives: To partially compensate the costs in connection with losses of revenue due to the decrease in passenger flights as a result of the novel coronavirus infection spread.
Background: The funds are assigned from the Reserve Fund of the Government of the Russian Federation to Rosaviatsiya, a federal government agency, which distributes the funds among the airports. Airports can use these funds to pay wages (except for top management), insurance fees and maintenance costs for buildings, equipment and transport.

Name of policy: Temporary prohibition on import of certain fuels
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Objectives:
1. Energy security
2. Stabilization of internal fuel market
Background: The list of fuels includes gasoline, diesel fuels, aviation (kerosene) fuel. The Government can review & extend the measure by July 15. The measure aims to protect domestic fuel producers from competition.

Name of policy: Tax Code amendments introducing more tax incentives for natural gas development in the Arctic
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Increasing oil and particularly gas extraction in the Arctic and promoting the development of maritime transport.
Background: The measure is aimed at increasing oil and particularly gas extraction in the Arctic and promoting the development of maritime transport.

Name of policy: Full tariff relief for small business customers in stress
Stage: electricity storage or transmission or distribution
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Support small businesses that suffer due to COVID-19.
Background: Network charges will be rebated for small business customers experiencing financial stress and who are mothballing as a result of COVID-19 from April to June.

Name of policy: Battery energy storage system (BESS) for the Darwin – Katherine System
Stage: electricity storage or transmission or distribution
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Ministry for Renewables, Energy and Essential Services
Objectives: Address system security and reliability, encourage private investors and maximise the amount of renewable power in the network.
Background: Procurement of a large scale battery energy storage system (BESS) for the Darwin-Katherine system at a project cost of $30M.

Name of policy: Progressing the Strategic Regional Environmental Baseline Assessment to develop an onshore gas industry
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Objectives: Development of an onshore gas industry
Background: $11.8 million towards the development of an onshore gas industry in the Territory to progress the Strategic Regional Environmental Baseline Assessment (SREBA), which will be subsequently recouped through cost-recovery arrangements with industry, and continue implementation of the Hydraulic Fracturing recommendations.

Name of policy: Subsidized fuel prices halved against the backdrop of international oil price plunge
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: to adjust domestic fuel prices according to changes in export prices of crude oil
Background: Saudi Arabia has a long-standing policy of subsidizing consumers of petroleum products by regulating their prices at a below-market price level. In early 2020, oil price plummeted on the global market, which warranted a pass-through of price reductions on domestic consumers in Saudi Arabia. The May cut in domestic prices amounted to around 50%, bringing them at the below-market level again. Fuel price adjustment remains subject to change, according to changes in export prices of crude oil.

Name of policy: Waiving electricity bills for small to medium businesses
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Support small business customers due to COVID-19 impact
Background: 100 percent waiver to eligible small business customers and community service organizations. This effectively waives the payment of their first quarterly electricity bill issued on or after 1 April 2020 for energy consumed in the previous billing period, saving Tasmanian small businesses on average around $1000. Tasmania is pretty close to 100% hydro but it is linked to the mainland so occasionally imports coal power. Since it is close to 100% hydro, this policy is categorized as clean conditional.

Name of policy: Regulatory measures: abolition of cap on fundable maximum capacity for solar; target for offshore wind power raised from 15 to 20 GW in 2030; regulation on minimum distances between wind turbines and nearest homes relaxed
Stage: electricity generation
Objectives: To further promote the expansion of renewable energies
Background: To further promote the expansion of renewable energies, the cap on the funding of photovoltaics ("Solardeckel") at a capacity of 52 GW will be abolished immediately. The expansion target for offshore wind power will be raised from 15 to 20 GW in 2030. Regulation for wind turbines (minimum distance of 1,000 meters to next home) will be relaxed. The federal states will be given the opportunity to stipulate lower minimum distances. This also creates an opportunity for local authorities and residents to benefit more from the financial returns of wind power.

Name of policy: Tasmania Renewable Hydrogen Action Plan
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Ministry of Energy and Ministry for State Growth
Objectives: Becoming the nation's renewable hydrogen industry epicenter.
Background: Tasmania wants to use its existing renewable energy to make green hydrogen. $20 million will be in the form of grants, another $20 million in the form of loans, and the final $10 million of support services including competitive electricity supply arrangements and payroll tax relief.

Name of policy: Reduction of the Mines Safety Levy
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Reduction of Mines Safety Levy by 20% from 1 July 2020 to provide relief to mining companies.
Background: The McGowan Government is reducing the Mines Safety Levy by 20 percent (from 21c to 17c) from July 1, 2020, to provide relief to mining companies.

Name of policy: Additional funding to support the CopperString 2.0 high voltage transmission line
Stage: electricity storage or transmission or distribution
Objectives: Extending the national electricity grid and create thousands of minerals mining and industrial manufacturing jobs
Background: Extending the national electricity grid from Townsville across the North to Mount Isa, CopperString is expected to underpin the creation of thousands of minerals mining and industrial manufacturing jobs for generations to come and stimulate large-scale renewable energy investment.

Name of policy: Renewable energy training facility
Stage: non-applicable (non-energy measure)
Objectives: Building renewable skills and jobs
Background: The facility will provide skills training for 750 apprentices annually and assist approximately 26,000 licensed electricians with further training in solar and other renewable energy work.

Name of policy: Opening up of 7,000km of land for coal and gas exploration
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Objectives: Expand resources sector.
Background: Five parcels released for tender around coal and gas-rich rich Surat and Bowen Basins

Name of policy: Bailout of Condor
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: The German government and the Hessian state government
Background: Condor received a €550m loan guarantee from the federal and Hessian government: €294m as corona-aid and €256m to refinance the bridging loan the airline received following the 2019 bankruptcy of Thomas Cook.

Name of policy: Bailout of TUI AG (including TUI Fly and cruiseships)
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Background: The total government bailout of TUI amounts to EUR 4.8 billion after the announcement in December 2020 of a last package of 1.8 billion euros. this will include 1.3 billion euros from the state - amassed from federal fund WSF, state-run lender KfW and a state debt guarantee -- together with 500 million euros from a shareholder capital increase. Previously, The TUI Group has been granted a loan of €1.8bn for its airline, cruise, hotel, and travel agency operations. For lack of exact breakdown by activity we are assigning the whole amount to oil and oil products as the main fuel for the airline and cruise ships, noting the lack of environmental conditionalities. It was also granted a 1.2 billion euros aid package in August 2020 to provide sufficient liquidity to the tour operator back then.

, https://ca.reuters.com/article/idUSASN000APO
Accessed 07 December 2020

Name of policy: $100 million electricity bill relief for small and medium businesses
Stage: electricity storage or transmission or distribution
Objectives: Support small businesses, including sole traders, as a result of COVID-19.
Background: Sole traders, small and medium businesses will get a $500 rebate on their power bill. Any business consuming less than 100,000 kilowatt hours will receive the rebate, which will be automatically applied on business electricity bills

Name of policy: Deferred costs for exploration and license fees for the minerals and petroleum sectors
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Assist companies struggling from COVID-19 and oil price collapse.
Background: Immediate deferral of mineral exploration license fees and annual petroleum and geothermal license fees due in the next six months (now due December 2020), as well as a 12-month waiver of committed expenditure for all mineral exploration license holders and an expansion of allowable expenditures towards the minimum Petroleum Retentiion License requirements during periods of low oil prices.

Name of policy: Deferral of rent collection and annual fees for quarries and exploration companies
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Earth Resources Regulation of the Ministry of Resources
Objectives: Ease cash flow pressure on mining companies.
Background: Victoria's Earth Resources Regulation will defer the collection of rent and annual fees worth $3.5 million until January 2021 to aid the immediate cashflow of mines, quarries, and exploration companies.

Name of policy: Support for public transport within municipal budgets (economic stimulus package)
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Background: Covid-19 pandemic has reduced ticket revenues for public transport. The federal government will support the federal states in 2020 with the financing of local public transport through a one-time increase in regionalization funds in 2020.

Name of policy: Legislation to lift the moratorium on onshore conventional gas exploration
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Objectives: Boost local gas supply.
Background: The Victorian Government claims it is supporting an open and orderly restart of the onshore conventional gas industry and that production of the estimated resources could generate as much as $310 million annually for regional economies and create up to 6,400 jobs.

Name of policy: Modernization of buildings for energy efficiency (economic stimulus package)
Stage: energy efficiency
Objectives: Increase energy efficiency of buildings
Background: Funding for the CO2 building renovation programme will be increased by one billion euros to 2.5 billion euros for 2020 and 2021. The federal government's funding programmes for the energy-efficient renovation of municipal buildings are also being increased and a programme to promote climate adaptation measures in social institutions will be launched.

Name of policy: Reform to the energy market to incentivise reductions in energy demand (“Wholesale demand response mechanism rule”)
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: Incentive major energy users to scale down demand during peak periods.
Background: The energy regulator body approved a rule to allow major energy users to be rewarded for scaling down demand during peak periods.

Name of policy: Premiums doubled for EVs buyers (economic stimulus package)
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: To strengthen mobility while ensuring more sustainability and climate protection
Background: The state will double the existing premiums for buyers of EVs.

Name of policy: Aviation Industry Relief Package
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: These measures are in response to an unprecedented and likely sustained period of falling international and domestic aviation demand related to the impact of COVID-19.
Background: The support package will refund and waive aviation fuel excise, air service charges, and domestic and regional aviation security charges.

Name of policy: CEFC investment in Electric Vehicle charging infrastructure
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: Support JET Charge in the deployment of smart charging hardware under a services-based model, to help drive down the cost of smart and connected EV charging stations and make them more user friendly for drivers.
Background: Clean Energy Finance Corporation investment in JET Charge EV charging infrastructure through the Clean Energy Innovation Fund.

Name of policy: Introduction of a new vehicles tax based on their CO2 emissions
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: To strengthen mobility while ensuring more sustainability and climate protection
Background: Starting from January 2021, new registered vehicles will be taxed according to the CO2 emissions per km (for vehicles with emissions above 95g CO2/km). Owners of cars with emissions over 195 grams/km will pay double the surcharge.

Name of policy: Advancing Hydrogen Fund
Stage: several energy stages
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Clean Energy Finance Coroportation 2020 Investment Mandate handed down by the Energy Minister
Objectives: Investing in Australia’s emerging hydrogen industry to kick start jobs and exports from the sector.
Background: This fund will provide finance to projects looking to grow Australia’s renewable hydrogen sector, including developing new domestic supply chains, export infrastructure, and to help grow domestic demand for hydrogen.

Name of policy: Hydrogen foreign trade partnerships
Stage: several energy stages
Objectives: To import hydrogen from partnership countries, make their economies less dependent on fossil fuels, and cover Germany’s hydrogen needs
Background: Germany plans to build up hydrogen trade partnerships with countries in which hydrogen can be produced efficiently due to their geographical location. Based on German hydrogen technologies that would be developed in the next years, it is planned to import hydrogen from partnership countries, make their economies less dependent on fossil fuels and cover Germany’s hydrogen needs.  Suitable hydrogen storage processes for the global, cost-efficient transport of hydrogen are to be developed. The establishment of a European hydrogen society to promote and develop common international production capacities and infrastructures will be explored and promoted with sufficient European support.

Name of policy: ARENA funding to fast track renewables for hydrogen
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Objectives: ARENA aims to share knowledge on technical and commercial parameters for commercial-scale renewable hydrogen production for domestic and international markets.
Background: ARENA, the Australian Renewable Energy Agency has opened up AUD 70 million funding to develop a competitive hydrogen industry in Australia. In particular, support will be geared towards developing large scale electrolysers that will source electricity from renewable energy.
Archived Links to sources:
https://reneweconomy.com.au/arena-opens-70-million-funding-round-to-fast-track-renewables-for-hydrogen-58600/ Accessed on 21 May 2020
, https://arena.gov.au/blog/70-million-hydrogen-funding-round/ Accessed on 21 May 2020

Name of policy: National Hydrogen Strategy (part of the economic stimulus package)
Stage: several energy stages
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Federal Government/Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy
Objectives: To make Germany the world's supplier of state-of-the-art hydrogen technology
Background:
The switch from fossil fuels to hydrogen is to be promoted and funded both through investment grants in new plants and a new pilot program to support the operation of electrolysis plants based on the carbon contracts-for-difference approach. Most of the electricity required is to be generated in offshore wind farms and it is planned to build hydrogen power plants with a total output of up to 5 GW by 2030 and 10 GW by 2040. The strategy provides for the creation of a 25-member national hydrogen council made up of people from business, science and civil society. A mandatory quota for aviation fuel and a demand quota for climate-friendly steel will be examined, as well as overall hydrogen infrastructure development. 
In order for the National Hydrogen Strategy to be implemented, a total of €9 billion has been made available for the coming years. Under the Stimulus and Future Packages adopted in June 2020, €7 billion has been earmarked for funding hydrogen technology in Germany and another €2 billion for promoting international partnerships.

Name of policy: Purchase of natural gas power plants
Stage: electricity generation
Objectives: Securing power plant ownership under the provincial crown corporation in order to provide electricity
Background: Ontario Power Generation (a for-profit business entity owned by the province of Ontario) finalized a deal to purchase three natural gas assets from TC Energy. OPG generates around 50% of the electricity used in Ontario. These natural gas power plants were already in use by the province and represent a transfer of assets. This purchase deal was developed pre-COVID-19 but is included here. The current Ontario government previously canceled hundreds of renewable energy projects and declined an offer from neighboring Quebec to purchase hydropower.

Name of policy: Postponed deadline for companies to report greenhouse gas emissions data
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: Saskatchewan has suspended the requirement for companies to report greenhouse gas emissions data on time.

Name of policy: Deferral of environmental reporting programs and data reporting requirements
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: Saskatchewan has deferred environmental monitoring programs and associated requirements for industry to report data under these same programs in cases where there is no  “imminent risk” of impacting the environment. The province has also suspended the requirement for industrial and mining operations to report “sampling and analysis” of environmental protection-related data.

Name of policy: Suspension of penalties for oil and gas companies who breach environmental obligations
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: Saskatchewan has temporarily suspended enforcement of penalties for companies that have not reported on the condition and safety of oil and gas wells, as well as incidents such as fires and leaks.  Well operators are temporarily exempted from surveys to detect and fix leaks if the health and environmental risks are not imminent.

Name of policy: Flexibility on enforcement for companies who breach environmental obligations
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: Saskatchewan is taking into consideration the impacts of COVID-19 when companies breach environmental laws and obligations, including those related to greenhouse gas emissions.

Name of policy: Suspension of pursuing penalties for companies who breach environmental obligations
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: Quebec is taking into consideration the impacts of COVID-19 when pursuing penalties for companies who breach environmental obligations.

Name of policy: Fee deferrals for onshore petroleum drilling applications
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: Onshore Petroleum Drilling Application Fee and Onshore Petroleum Geophysical Exploration Application Fee payment deadlines have been postponed to June 30, 2020.

Name of policy: Air pollution emission fee deferrals
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: Industrial Air Emission Fee payment deadlines have been postponed to June 30, 2020.

Name of policy: Funding for critical air services to Northern and remote communities
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: Providing relief to the aviation industry and ensuring critical flights during COVID-19
Background: The federal government originally provided up to $17.3 million to the governments of Yukon, Northwest Territories, and Nunavut to support critical air services to Northern and remote communities, in partnership with investments by the territorial governments, to ensure the continued supply of food, medical supplies, and other essential goods and services to remote and fly-in communities. In September 2020 under the Safe Restart Agreement, an additional CAD 41.41 million was provided to the territories in support for air carriers to ensure reliable air service to remote communities.

Name of policy: Stimulus to advance highway projects in Manitoba
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: Create jobs and economic activity through infrastructure projects

Name of policy: Reduction in vehicle registration fees – Manitoba
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Reduce costs for consumers
Background: Most Manitobans will benefit from a $15 decrease to the existing $154 vehicle registration fee as a first step to reverse a 30 percent increase in these fees in 2012 by the previous administration. The government has cited COVD-19 as a rationale for the program.

Name of policy: Increased flexibility in environmental reporting
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: Companies are able to contact the government in cases where they are not able to comply with normal environmental rules due to COVID-19. The government will consider reasons related to the pandemic when addressing non-compliance.

Name of policy: Decrease in British Columbia natural gas levy
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: British Columbia Oil and Gas Commission
Objectives: Reducing costs to industry to limit economic impact of COVID-19
Background: The provincial government has lowered the amount payable for levies that companies pay to produce natural gas (from $0.85 per 1,000 m3 of marketable gas produced, to $0.77). The government noted that this change was meant to compensate for an increase in the orphan well levy. The orphan well levy is also currently suspended.

Name of policy: Temporary suspension of requirement for companies to report exceeding certain air quality guidelines in certain circumstances
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reduce burdens for industries impacted by COVID-19
Background: Alberta suspended the requirement for companies to immediately notify the provincial government when they exceed certain air quality guidelines from March 31 to July 15 2020. Companies are required to report these instances on a monthly basis, and this does not apply to all air quality exceedances.

Name of policy: Deadline extension for large, industrial greenhouse gas emitters to submit compliance reports and emissions reduction plans
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reduce burdens for industries impacted by COVID-19
Background: Citing COVID-19, Alberta has postponed the deadline for large, industrial greenhouse gas emitters to submit compliance reports and emissions reduction plans under the Technology Innovation and Emissions Reduction Regulation.

Name of policy: Reduction of environmental protections to prevent coal mining in the Foothills and Rockies
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Facilitate coal industry activity in Alberta
Background: The province of Alberta cancelled blanket environmental protections (in place since 1976), which makes it easier to pursue open-pit coal mine development in ecologically sensitive areas. This policy was reversed in February 2021.

Name of policy: Extension of fuel tax exemption permits
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Reducing costs for consumers, including industry, impacted by COVID-19
Background: The expiry date for Fuel Tax Exemption Permits, which allows permit holders to purchase tax-exempt marked gasoline and light fuel oil, which was set to expire on March 31, 2020 has been extended to June 30, 2020. Gasoline and carbon product retailers throughout the province are authorized to accept such permits and continue to sell marked diesel and light fuel oil exempt of gasoline and carbon tax to these permit holders up to and including June 30, 2020.

Name of policy: Delay of publication and implementation of the Clean Fuel Standard
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Allow adequate time for the development of regulations
Background: The Clean Fuel Standard will contribute to reducing Canada’s greenhouse gas emissions through the increased use of lower-carbon fuels, energy sources, and technologies. The standard, due to be published in spring 2020, has been delayed to fall. The implementation of regulations, originally slated for January 2020, has been broadened to 2020 (date unspecified). Although the standard will be weakend from the initial plan in the early years, it will be strengthened in the years following.

Name of policy: Extension of deadline for pollution data reporting by industry
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: The deadline for National Pollutant Release Inventory data by industry has been extended to July 31, 2020.

Name of policy: Extension of deadline for greenhouse gas emissions reporting by industry
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reducing burdens for industry during COVID-19
Background: The deadline for greenhouse gas emissions reporting by industry has been extended to July 31, 2020.

Name of policy: Streamlined review process for companies proposing exploratory oil and gas drilling off the coast of Newfoundland and Labrador
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Objectives: Ensure the offshore oil and gas industry remains globally competitive
Background: A new regulation allowing companies proposing exploratory oil and gas drilling in Newfoundland and Labrador to bypass the usual federal impact assessment process. Companies would need to meet alternative environmental conditions.

Name of policy: Suspension of additional reporting requirements for oil, gas and coal companies
Stage: exploration or production or processing or storage or transportation
Mechanism: regulatory rollback or non-govt fee break or waiver (IT)
Objectives: Reduce burdens for industries impacted by COVID-19
Background: The province of Alberta suspended environmental reporting requirements for oil, gas and coal companies including deadlines for oil and gas companies to demonstrate proper shut off of inactive wells; requirements for companies operating coal mines to submit annual reports (including key environmental data); requirements for oil and gas companies to report on the condition of wells. This was in place from March 31 to July 15, 2020, ending four weeks earlier than the period announced initially. In addition, over the same time period, the province suspended a broad section of requirements for oilsands companies to monitor environmental conditions, including reports on leaks, wetlands and wildlife and monitoring,  deaths of birds on tailings ponds,  as well as active checks on groundwater, soil, wildlife and tailings ponds, etc.

Name of policy: Fixed electricity price for all time-of-use electricity customers
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: Reduce the economic burden for consumers during COVID-19
Background: Ontario has introduced a fixed electricity price, known as the COVID-19 Recovery Rate, of 12.8 cents per kWh, which will be automatically applied to all time-of-use customers 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. This follows previous announcements related to cost relief for electricity in Ontario for residential, farm, and small business consumers announced on March 24, 2020.

Name of policy: Cost relief for electricity for residential, farm and small business consumers
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Objectives: Reduce the economic burden for consumers during COVID-19
Background: Most of Ontario's electricity is low-carbon but some is natural gas. The Ontario government introduced cost-relief measures for electricity for select consumers and expanded eligibility to their Low-Income Energy Assistance Program while ensuring consumers were not cut off from electricity supplies. At least CAD 175 million has been disbursed so far.

Name of policy: Funding for airlines in Northwest Territories
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Background:
On May 8, CAD 8.7 million in funding was announced by the territorial government to support Northwest Territories (NWT) passenger-based airlines who offer scheduled service during the COVID-19 pandemic. An additional CAD 2.9 million was announced in June and an additional CAD 3.021 million was announced in September.

Part of this support comes from a CAD 130 million allocation by the federal government on April 14, 2020 to assist the territories and northern businesses during the pandemic. The Government of NWT is providing this funding to NWT airlines to ensure that companies can continue to provide scheduled connections into communities, providing essential goods, like food and medical supplies. Additional support is expected to be announced.

Name of policy: Waiving of landing fees at Northwest Territories airports and additional fees for businesses operating at airports
Stage: energy use (all energy types, consumption in transport, household use, buildings etc)
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Providing relief to the aviation industry and ensuring critical flights during COVID-19
Background: All landing fees have been waived at airports in the Northwest Territories. The territory has also waived leases, licenses and concession fees for all businesses operating at Northwest Territories airports.

Name of policy: Rent relief for public land
Stage: several energy stages
Mechanism: tax or royalty or govt fee break (GRF)
Objectives: Reduce costs to industry during COVID-19
Background: Rent relief is available to all holders of existing recreational, residential, and commercial and mining surface dispositions on public land. Surface dispositions are usually leases, but there are a small number of other types of dispositions such as easements or licenses of occupation, that will also be eligible for relief. This measure does not apply to applications received after April 1, 2020. The measure covers mines, bulk fuel companies, trucking companies, and more.

Name of policy: Large employer emergency financing facility (LEEFF) for major companies
Stage: several energy stages
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Government of Canada; Canada Development Investment Corporation
Objectives: Providing liquidity via loans of last-resort to industries impacted by COVID-19
Background: Under this program, the Government of Canada introduced some conditionality measures for access to funding. Companies must disclose climate risks according to the Financial Stability Board (FSB)'s Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosure (TCFD) and sustainability plans to qualify. Emergency loans of CAD 60 million or more will be provided in certain cases to large employers with revenues of over CAD 300 million per year. The objective is to prevent bankruptcies (government to be a lender of last resort). Companies must have significant operations or large numbers of employees in Canada.

Name of policy: Expansion of eligibility for the Business Credit Availability Program (BCAP) for oil and gas companies and mid-sized companies; creation of Mid-Market Financing Program
Stage: several energy stages
Legislation and Endorsing Agency: Business Development Canada; Export Development Canada
Objectives: Provide liquidity to oil and gas producers
Background:
Alberta and the oil and gas sector lobbied for up to CAD 30 billion in liquidity for producers to manage impacts related to the pandemic. This federal measure ensures energy producers are included and prioritized in the Business Credit Availability Program that is provided through Business Development Canada and Export Development Canada. On May 11, the government announced it would expand the BCAP program to mid-sized companies with larger financing needs, including loans of up to CAD 60 million per company and loan guarantees of up to CAD 80 million.  On June 18th, the federal government announced the Mid-Market Guarantee and Financing Program as part of BCAP, which is intended to fund operational cashflow needs with support for sectors "particularly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and/or the recent decline in oil and gas prices," such as oil and gas by providing loans between CAD 12.5 million and CAD 60 million prior to September 30, 2020. 90% of financing for this program is provided by Business Development Canada. 

As of July 8, 2020, total funding provided through BCAP for all sectors was at least CAD 81.25 billion, including CAD 40 billion through the Small and Medium-sized Enterprise Loan and Guarantee Program. No figures are currently available for the Mid-Market Guarantee and Financing Program.
